item.title: Teaching
item.description: Machine Learning (6.867) [Course website] Principles, techniques, and algorithms in machine learning from the point of view of statistical inference; representation, generalization, and model selection; and methods such as linear/additive models, active learning, boosting, support vector machines, non-parametric Bayesian methods, hidden Markov models, and Bayesian networks. The course will give the student the basic ideas and intuition behind modern machine learning methods as well as a bit more formal understanding of how, why, and when they work.

item.title: Contact Us
item.description:
a {color: #A31F34;} Email David’s email: dsontag {@ | at} mit.edu
FAQs How can I join the group as a PhD student? Graduate admissions are handled at the department level at MIT, so please first apply to the MIT EECS or MIT MEMP departments. For advice on CS PhD admissions, Jean Yang and Philip Guo have written useful guides. How can I join the group as a UROP/SuperUROP or MEng student?

item.title: Mission
item.description: Machine Learning Perspective Making ML work in high-stakes settings Recently developed techniques in machine learning have proven adept at solving problems in computer vision, natural language processing, board games, video games, and other domains where computers had previously struggled to outperform humans. However, deployment in high-stakes settings is still limited, for good reasons: Predictive models alone may be insufficient - we may care about causal questions (as in personalized medicine), not just predictive ones.

item.title: People
item.description: Our team consists of PhD students, research scientists, and clinical collaborators. Current members Irene is from Atlanta and is interested in graphical models for disease progression and patient subtyping. Irene is from Atlanta and is interested in graphical models for disease progression and patient subtyping. Mike is from the suburbs of Boston, and is interested in causal inference, as well as using probabilistic models for dealing with dataset shift
